questions.question_text: An analyst is reviewing the Cisco FMC reports for the week. They notice that some peer-to-peer applications are being used on the network and they must identify which poses the greatest risk to the environment. Which report gives the analyst this information?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I agree.
I just don't understand the difference between the three.
The description of “network” suggests that it is probably D, but I would like to know how to distinguish between the three in the official guide.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/secure-firewall/management-center/admin/760/management-center-admin-76/report-reports.html#:~:text=Risk%20Report%20Templates

Selected Answer: D
User Risk Report is not a valid option, the rest of them are.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/secure-firewall/management-center/admin/710/management-center-admin-71/report-reports.html

Network Risk Report sounds correct here. Attacks Risk Report is focused more on IPS events.

Selected Answer: D
D seems to be correct
On FMC>Overview>Report templates you have 3 options for risk reports:
Advanced Malware
Attacks Risk Report
Network risk report

Selected Answer: A
I think A will be the better answer, as the other three are report templates. There only 2 types of report:
1. Risk report
2. Standard report

questions.question_text: An administrator receives reports that users cannot access a cloud-hosted web server. The access control policy was recently updated with several new policy additions and URL filtering. What must be done to troubleshoot the issue and restore access without sacrificing the organization's security posture?

choices.C: Create a new access control policy rule to allow ports 80 and 443 to the FQDN of the web server.
choices.B: Identify the blocked traffic in the Cisco FMC connection events to validate the block, and modify the policy to allow the traffic to the web server.
choices.D: Verify the blocks using the packet capture tool and create a rule with the action monitor for the traffic.
choices.A: Download a PCAP of the traffic attempts to verify the blocks and use the flexconfig objects to create a rule that allows only the required traffic to the destination server.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Identify the blocked traffic in the Cisco FMC connection events to validate the block, and modify the policy to allow the traffic to the web server.

To troubleshoot this issue and restore access without sacrificing the organization's security posture, the administrator should use the Cisco FMC connection events to identify the traffic that is being blocked and validate the block. Once the traffic has been identified, the access control policy can be modified to allow the traffic to the cloud-hosted web server. Creating a new access control policy rule or allowing all traffic to the web server could potentially introduce security risks, so it is important to only allow the necessary traffic and ensure that the policy aligns with the organization's security requirements. Using the packet capture tool or flexconfig objects could be used to troubleshoot the issue but would likely be more time-consuming and complex than using the connection events dashboard.

B. Identify the blocked traffic in the Cisco FMC connection events to validate the block, and modify the policy to allow the traffic to the web server.

Since the issue occurred after a recent update to the access control policy, it is likely that one or more of the new policy additions or URL filtering rules is causing the block. The first step in troubleshooting the issue is to identify the blocked traffic and validate the block. This can be done by checking the Cisco FMC connection events to see which traffic is being blocked and why. Once the issue is identified, the policy can be modified to allow the required traffic to the web server, without sacrificing the organization's security posture. Creating a new access control policy rule to allow ports 80 and 443 to the FQDN of the web server (A) could be a temporary solution but it may not address the root cause of the issue and may introduce security risks. Using the action monitor for the traffic (C) may not resolve the issue since the traffic is already being blocked. Using flexconfig objects to create a rule that allows only the required traffic (D) may be a more complex and time-consuming solution.

Selected Answer: B
identifying the blocked traffic in the Cisco FMC connection events to validate the block, and modifying the policy to allow the traffic to the web server is a valid troubleshooting step to restore access without sacrificing the organization's security posture.

Selected Answer: B
I think B is the correct answer

Selected Answer: B
So since this is a cisco cert, I dont think cisco want you to externally examine pcap files, which is why I wouldnt use A
C and D are to unspecific, packet capture does not get URL-filtering iirc and allowing all traffic surely isnt the way either.
This is why I go with B

choices.C: Filter the connection events by the destination port 8699/udp.
choices.B: Filter the connection events by the source port 8699/udp.
choices.D: Use the context explorer to see the destination port blocks.
choices.A: Use the context explorer to see the application blocks by protocol.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The engineer should filter the connection events by the destination port 8699/udp to identify the devices that have been trying to connect to it over the last week. This will provide a list of IP addresses and devices that require access to the server over the specified port. The engineer can then create an access control policy rule to allow traffic from these specific devices while maintaining the organization's security posture. Using the context explorer or looking at application blocks by protocol may not provide the necessary information to identify the devices that require access to the server over this specific port.

Selected Answer: C
D would be possible in my opinion, but over the top. 
In real-live everybody would go for the conn-events?...

Selected Answer: C
I think C

Selected Answer: C
A. Use the context explorer to see the application blocks by protocol.
-> Well, since were only after 1 application and 1 protocol, why would I use the context explorer?

B. Filter the connection events by the source port 8699/udp.
-> No, its about dest port

C. Filter the connection events by the destination port 8699/udp.
-> Makes the most sense, since we want to see all connections to the destination port

D. Use the context explorer to see the destination port blocks.
Could be another option, but the context exporer is more high level than seeing directly the destination port blocks, so I go with C

questions.question_text: An engineer is reviewing a ticket that requests to allow traffic for some devices that must connect to a server over 8699/udp. The request mentions only one IP address, 172.16.18.15, but the requestor asked for the engineer to open the port for all machines that have been trying to connect to it over the last week. Which action must the engineer take to troubleshoot this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
100% sure it is D - Enforcement

comments.content: I forgot the last line: "You can use this intelligence in a custom integration with Umbrella to add additional domains to block." <==there it is

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
"What can I do with the Umbrella Enforcement API?
The Umbrella Enforcement API allows partners and customers with their own security information and event management (SIEM) or threat intelligence source to inject "events" or threat intelligence into their Umbrella environment."

straight from Cisco ^^ :
https://developer.cisco.com/learning/labs/2-Umbrella-Enforcement-API-Explained-v-1-1/introduction-to-the-cisco-umbrella-enforcement-api/

Selected Answer: D
The Umbrella Enforcement API is a feature that allows for automated addition of new domains to a security enforcement list.

Answer D

Selected Answer: D
The Umbrella Enforcement API can be used to automatically push blocking of domains from the Cisco Threat Response interface to Cisco Umbrella.

Selected Answer: D
The enforcement API allows automatic pushing of blocking of domains from Cisco Threat Response to Cisco Umbrella. This API automates the blocking of domains based on indicators of compromise (IOCs) discovered during an investigation in Cisco Threat Response.

Selected Answer: B
Which API ? ---> is this question a joke? 
There is only the REST API.

comments.content:
Bad Post - cannot delete. 
Go with enfocement..

discussion.content:
Instvestigate could also be an option, but enforcement is the low level one:
https://support.umbrella.com/hc/en-us/articles/360030979772-Linking-Cisco-Threat-Response-CTR-to-Umbrella

questions.question_text: While integrating Cisco Umbrella with Cisco Threat Response, a network security engineer wants to automatically push blocking of domains from the Cisco Threat Response interface to Cisco Umbrella. Which API meets this requirement?

choices.D: The Cisco IPS is configured in detection mode.
choices.C: The Cisco IPS has been configured to be in fail-open mode.
choices.A: The upstream router has a misconfigured routing protocol.

questions.question_text: An engineer is working on a LAN switch and has noticed that its network connection to the inline Cisco IPS has gone down. Upon troubleshooting, it is determined that the switch is working as expected. What must have been implemented for this failure to occur?

discussion.content: Cisco IPS??? I thought that boat anchor was EOL long ago!

Selected Answer: B
If link-state propagation is enabled on a switch, it can cause the switch to incorrectly detect a link failure, which can lead to network connectivity issues. In the case of the inline Cisco IPS, the switch may detect a link failure due to the IPS not responding to certain types of traffic, even though the IPS is functioning properly.

Selected Answer: B
B is a better answer

Selected Answer: B
B is better:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/firepower/60/configuration/guide/fpmc-config-guide-v60/fpmc-config-guide-v60_chapter_01011010.html

Selected Answer: B
I would guess "B", assuming that the link failed on the other side and the FTD propagated the link state to the LAN segment
